hints.content:
When the disease allele of the _APOE_ gene is transcribed into mRNA, the mutation in the DNA will also be found in the mRNA (since the mRNA is made using the DNA as a template):

$\text{5'-...GUG}\red{\text C}\text{GCGGC...-3'}$

When the disease allele's  mRNA is translated (using the same frame as for the normal allele of _APOE_), the mutation will result in a protein with an altered amino acid sequence. The altered sequence can be found by looking up each codon in the codon table.


Codons: $\quad \quad\:\:\text{5'-...GUG }\red{\text C}\text{GC GGC...-3'}$

[[☃ explanation 2]]

The disease allele's mRNA specifies the following series of amino acids:

Codons: $\quad \quad\:\:\text{5'-...GUG }\red{\text C}\text{GC GGC...-3'}$

Amino acids: $\:\:\:\:\text{N - ...Val - }\red{\text{Arg}}\text{ - Gly... - C}$

Comparing this amino acid sequence to that of the normal protein, we can see that Cys (cysteine) is replaced with Arg (arginine):

Normal APOE protein: $\quad \quad\quad\:\:\quad \text{N - ...Val - Cys - Gly... - C}\\$

Disease-related APOE protein: $\:\:\:\:\:\text{N - ...Val - }\red{\text{Arg}}\text{ - Gly... - C}\\$
**$\text{Cys}$ is replaced with $\text{Arg}$ in the abnormal (mutant) APOE protein**.

question.content:
The human *APOE* gene encodes a protein that helps transport certain nutrients into brain cells. A short section of the normal _APOE_ gene is shown below, along with the stretch of mRNA it encodes and the sequence of amino acids it specifies:

DNA:



$\text{5'-...GTGTGCGGC...-3'} \\
{\text{3'-...CACACGCCG...-5'}}$

mRNA:

$\text{5'-...GUGUGCGGC...-3'}\\$

Protein:

$\text{N - ...Val - Cys - Gly... - C}\\$


A different, less common allele of the  _APOE_ gene encodes an abnormal protein and is linked to increased risk of  Alzheimer's disease. The disease allele has the mutation shown below:

$\text{5'-...GTG}\red{\text C}\text{GCGGC...-3'} \\
{\text{3'-...CAC}\red{\text G}\text{CGCCG...-5'}}$

**How is the abnormal (mutant) APOE protein different from the normal protein?**
